Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the implementation of a disruptive technology that can transform the landscape of energy storage. This project aims to combine millions of copper wire used to transport electricity with energy storage technologies that are typically expensive, large, or heavy. This approach has many value generating applications in the aerospace, automotive, energy, defense, and IT industries. In the event of a power shortage in a data center or server room, websites or cloud services are at risk of going offline. By combining energy storage with copper wires, this project would ensure that these services stay online during a shortage and will maximize space in server rooms by removing backup batteries enabling the companies to offer more services. This same technology could cut the weight soldiers carry during military operations, reduce the cost of energy, improve the output of electric vehicles or wind turbines.

This I-Corps project will further develop a cable-based-supercapacitor (CSC) technology. The CSC will simultaneously store and transport electricity. This is accomplished by a novel method of growing high aspect ratio nano-whiskers on the surface of copper cable/fibers which greatly increases the surface area. This increase in surface area provides highly enhanced energy storage capability to the CSC. A proof-of-concept device has demonstrated the CSC's function and durability in potential commercial applications.

Institution.Name: The University of Central Florida Board of Trustees
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF CENTRAL FLORIDA BOARD OF TRUSTEES, THE

POR.DRECONTENT:
The National Science Foundation’s (NSF) I-Corps Program provided financial support and valuable training that greatly improved the odds of launching a new company that would be commercializing technology developed at the University of Central Florida (UCF). The financial support enabled a team comprised of one student, one professor, and one business mentor to travel across the country to engage with over 100 different businesses about problems they are facing, how technology is adopted, and how the industry works as a whole.

 

The training support helped the team understand how to effectively engage with various stake holders such as businesses, their employees, and partners that might be required to successfully commercialize the technology. The training also provided the team with the necessary skills required to launch a high-tech company which would commercialize high-risk, high-reward technology, and what steps are required to be successful. Each week the team presented to a group of instructors about who they met, what they learned, and what changes should be made to their business model to improve odds of success. The instructors would also present weekly goals and tasks that forced the team to consider different risks and how to mitigate them. This was particularly helpful to the team.

 

At the beginning of this NSF program, the team had intended to use this technology in industries with long adoption cycles such as the Defense Industry and the Clean-Tech Industry. The odds of success for this plan was not great. By participating in this program, the team identified a faster path to market and thus faster path to revenue which would require less funding to successfully get to. In other words, the I-Corps program saved the team from wasting significant time and money giving the team a better chance for successful commercialization. 

 

As a result of the NSF I-Corps Program, the start-up company has two direct employees and is contracting over $100k worth of high-tech work to various different groups including UCF to continue the commercialization effort in 2018. The instruction and lessons learned in the program have helped the team effectively communicate their business with investors, customers, and partners which has led to the team receiving grants, investment, and significant market traction which will translate to revenue by the first or second quarter of 2019.

 

 

The NSF I-Corps Program helped this team realize that it is not just what the technology does or how it works, but more importantly what the technology accomplishes (its value) for various customers. Using this core lesson, the team has gone on to further commercialize this technology and is closing in on launching the product in the market, hiring additional employees, and making a significant positive impact on the central Florida community in the coming year! 

 


Last Modified: 07/11/2018
Modified by: Jayan Thomas
